section.title: Installation

note.para: You only need to read this section if you are installing &progname;. If you are a user none of this paragraph is relevant. Please ask your Administrator for a URL.

section.para: &progname; is normally installed on a Linux machine. If you attenpt to install it on another operating system you do so at your own risk.
You will require root acces to install &progname; as there may be a number of PHP and application prerequisites to install.

warning.para: Installing &progname; may make your machine insecure during the installation process. Please ensure that you are behind a firewall.

section.title: PHP
section.para: Installed Version Test: php -v
If you don't have it and your OS doesn't provide official packages, visit . Although &progname; runs with PHP &min-php-ver;, it's a good idea to be using the latest stable version.

The following PHP Extensions are required.
posix - required to set up the application.
session - used to monitor logins beteen pages.
pgsql - PHP Postgresql Native Driver.
Installed Extension Test: php -m
If you don't have the required extensions and you OS does not provide them to may have to reinstall PHP from source.

section.title: Apache Webserver
section.para: Installed Version Test: view the default welcome page at http://<your-machine>/

You have freedom of choice here, pretty much any web server that is capable of running PHP scripts will work. However, we strongly recommend using the Apache web server (either 1.3.x or 2.x), and the installation instructions usually assume you are using it.
If you don't have Apache and your OS doesn't provide official packages, visit .

section.title: Database
section.para: &progname; supports pgsql as its database server.

section.title: Install Postgresql
section.para: Installed Version Test: psql -V
If you don't have it and your OS doesn't provide official packages, visit . You need PostgreSQL version &min-pg-ver; or higher.
If you install from something other than a packaging/installation system, such as .rpm (Redhat Package), or .deb (Debian Package), make sure the PostgreSQL server is started when the machine boots.

section.title: Webtemplate
section.para: Download a copy of &progname; and place in a directory accessable by your web server user (normally apache or www).
There is no need to set any file permissions as the install program will carry out that task for you.

section.title: Install SMARTY
section.para: &progname; requires SMARTY to display its output. Smarty is a template engine for PHP, facilitating the separation of presentation (HTML/CSS) from application logic. &progname; requires SMARTY version &min-smarty-ver;. The SMARTY homepage is .

SMARTY is installed using Composer. If you do not have Composer installed on your server the instructions for installing it can be found at . If you only require Composer for &progname; then you should install it locally in the top directory of &progname;

One you have installed Composer run the following command php composer.phar install --no-dev. This will install the correct version of the Smarty Template Engine in the vendor directory. if you leave the --no-dev option out all dependancies including those for developing the application will be installed.

warning.para: Poorly-configured installations can give attackers full access to your systemt. Please take the security parts of these guidelines seriously, even for &progname; machines hidden away behind your firewall. Be certain to read for some important security tips.

section.title: Database
&progname;
section.para: In order to configure &progname; you require root access to your webserver as you need to run a PHP install script. This script configures &progname;, setsup your database and sets file permissions within the &progname; directory structure.
To configure &progname; carry out the following instructions:

step.para: Copy config.php.dist to config.php. Open config.php in your favourite text editor.
config.php contains the following elements and all must be completed for &progname; to be installed correctly.
Run the following command from the &progname; directory: ./install.php --check-modules
Install any missing modules and run the command again omitting the --check-modules switch. ./install.php

section.para: &progname; should now be configured for use. If the install failed correct the errors and run the install command again.

section.title: Apache Webserver
section.para: Configure your webserver according to the appropriate section below. Currently &progname; only supports Apache with mod_php.

section.title: Apache with mod_php
section.para: To configure Apache to work with &progname; carry out the following instructions.

step.para: Load httpd.conf in your editor. In distributions like RedHat this can be found in /etc/hpptd/conf. If your distribution has configuration tools such as Yast in Suse it is recommended that you use them.

Apache users the <Directory> directive to set permissions. The following lines need to be added to the directive that applies to the location of &progname;. If it does not exist. This example assumes that &progname; resides in /src/www/&progname;.
step.programlisting: <Directory /src/www/webtemplate/base> AllowOverride None Order allow,deny Allow from all DirectoryIndex index.php </Directory>
step.para: These instructions tell Apache to look for index.php if someone only types the directory name into the browser. It prevents .htaccess files overriding global permissions. It also allows access from any IP address
Set up your access to the directory as either an alias or virtual host. Follow the instructions for your webserver to do this.
Restart the webserver and access &progname; using your chosen URL.

section.title: Documentation
section.para: If you have installed &progname; from a tarball then the en documentation will have been installed by default as part of the tarball.

If you have installed from git or updated an existing installation from svn or by appling a patch you will need to create the updated documentation files. To create the documentation files (html and pdf) you will need to install xmlto, dblatex and xsltproc.

Once you have ensured the three commands have been installed navigate to the base/docs and run the following command ./makedocs.php --with-pdf. This will make the html and pdf documentation for each installed language pack.
